Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, the script for our new service open in front of me. The phone rang, and I launched into my pitch, but as usual, the prospect interrupted with a barrage of technical questions. My script only skimmed the surface, and I felt the familiar anxiety rise—my supervisor expected me to handle objections smoothly, to keep the call moving, to close the sale. I glanced at the clock. It was nearly time for Wednesday evening church service, something I’d promised myself and my faith community I would never miss. The pastor always said our presence mattered, that worship and fellowship were not just obligations but lifelines. Yet, the call queue was long, and my manager had made it clear that leaving early was frowned upon, especially during a new campaign. My heart pounded as I tried to answer the customer’s questions, torn between the demands of my job and the pull of my faith. I could feel the weight of both expectations pressing in, each one asking for more than I felt able to give.
